title-group.article-title: A critical evaluation of mechanical models for sandwich beams

author-notes.corresp: Lorenzo Bardella, DICATA, University of Brescia, via Branze, 43-25123 Brescia, Italy. Email: lorenzo.bardella@ing.unibs.it

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: We focus on the description of the stress state of sandwich beams under bending and shear, a non-trivial task if Saint-Venant's principle does not hold, as it is the case if the skins are somewhat stiffer than the core. Each of the analytical structural models available in literature turns out to be accurate for a limited range of relative stiffness between core and skins, or sandwich heterogeneity. For a simply supported sandwich beam subject to uniform transversal load, we evaluate the stress by means of (a) the classical theory relying on the linear cross-section kinematics, appropriate if Saint-Venant's principle holds, (b) the structural theory based on the zig-zag warping (e.g. Krajcinovic D. Sandwich beam analysis. J Appl Mech, Trans ASME 1972; 39(3): 773–778), and (c) the higher-order theory of Frostig et al. (Frostig Y, Baruch M, Vilnay O, et al. High-order theory for sandwich-beam behavior with transversely flexible core. J Eng Mech, Trans ASCE 1992; 118(5): 1026–1043), the latter usually appropriate when the core is much softer than the skins. The results are compared, for several combinations of material and geometrical parameters, with those of finite element simulations in which the sandwich is modelled as a plane stress continuum. This comparison allows us to provide some graphs which can help in selecting the model appropriate for each sandwich heterogeneity. This is accomplished in terms of non-dimensional material and geometrical parameters the sandwich heterogeneity depends on. We identify and discuss two levels of heterogeneity at which one should switch analytical model: one level is related to the validity of Saint-Venant's principle, while the other level is concerned with the definition of antiplane sandwich.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
We wish to investigate the relation between the heterogeneity peculiar of sandwich beams and the analytical structural models to be employed to accurately describe the sandwich stress state under bending and shear, within the linear elastic regime. We limit our attention to sandwiches whose cross-section is symmetric with respect to the neutral axis, say z, x being the beam axis. In other words, we consider sandwiches whose top and bottom layers, i.e. the skins, are identical, having relevant Young's modulusa
aHere and henceforth, the relevant Young's modulus of each layer of a sandwich beam is the longitudinal elastic modulus along the beam axis x, independent of the possible anisotropy of the layer. Es and arbitrary thickness t. The skins are assumed to be perfectly bonded to the core (i.e. the intermediate layer). The cross-section heterogeneity is expressed in terms of the ratios between the longitudinal elastic moduli of core and skins (1)ε=EcEs and between the skin and core thicknesses (2)γ=tc Since we leave ϵ free to assume any value within the range (0, 1] and we wish to investigate the case of very thick skins as well, finding an accurate and simple analytical model for any situation is unfeasible [1–3].

The behaviour of a sandwich beam may be strongly affected by the exact way the loads are applied and the constraints are realised, details usually neglected in structural beam models. For instance, should the core be much softer than the skins (ϵ = 0.01 or much less is possible, especially in sandwiches whose core is made up of foam), the stress state in a simply supported sandwich beam may be largely different whether a uniformly distributed transversal load (i.e. acting along y) is applied on the top skin or on the bottom skin; moreover, the resulting stress state may also be strongly dependent, in any section, on the exact way the reaction forces are developed by the supports: are they distributed along the whole sandwich height or are they localised on one skin? In other words, the problem may become two-dimensional. Because of this, let us indicate this feature, partly or totally left out of consideration by structural sandwich models, as the ‘lack of Saint-Venant's principle’.

We compare the results of plane stress finite element simulations with the predictions of (a) the classical theory based on the linear cross-section kinematics (see the works [1, 2, 4, 5] and references therein), (b) the structural theory based on the zig-zag warping (see, e.g., the works [1, 2, 6–9]), and (c) the higher-order theory of Frostig et al. [10, 11], whose peculiar feature is the inclusion of the contribution of the core deformability along the thickness direction, y.

Here and henceforth, the classical modelling relying on the linear cross-section kinematics is referred to as first-order shear deformation (FOSD) modelling (summarised in the `FOSD modelling' section), that is the simplest possible theory accounting for the shear deformation. It is developed within the context of the single-layer theory for laminate structures and is based on the Timoshenko model for homogeneous beams, in which the heterogeneity enters the model through the bending stiffness D and the shearing rigidity S, the estimation of the latter being usually considered the main difficulty for a successful application of the FOSD model. Different estimates of S lead to different FOSD models. By pretending there is no warping, the FOSD models predict a stress state which just depends on the bending moment M(x) and shear force V(x) acting on the section considered; hence, in statically determinate beams, as concerned here, all FOSD models predict the same stress state, estimated by straightforward extensions of the classical theories of Bernoulli–Navier and Jourawski. FOSD models cannot account for the dependence of the stress on the way the boundary conditions are applied along the cross-section and, then, we indicate the stress state they predict as ‘à la de Saint-Venant’.

Contrariwise, the model of Frostig et al. [10, 11] (summarised in the `The higher-order theory of Frostig et al. [10, 11]' section) aims at describing the effects of concentrated loads when the core is very soft with respect to the skins, so that it accounts, at some extent, for the stress dependence on the way the boundary conditions are applied. This is done by including the contribution due to the direct deformation εy along the core thickness. The sandwich is modelled as two Euler–Bernoulli beams (i.e. the skins) connected by a two-dimensional plane stress continuum (i.e. the core), where the normal stress σx along the longitudinal axis x is neglected, i.e., in words typical of sandwich structures [1], the sandwich is assumed to be ‘antiplane’. The resulting model is quite complicated although it neglects the shear deformation in the skins, besides the antiplane assumption. This last approximation implies that the shear stress τxy within the core is independent upon y (i.e. uniform along the thickness) and makes the Frostig model unable to well represent the stress state in sandwiches with a not-too-soft core.

The structural model based on the zig-zag warping (i.e. piecewise linear, as depicted in Figure 1), summarised in the `FOSD modelling' section (see, e.g. works [6, 7, 9]), is not ‘à la de Saint-Venant’ as well, because the stress state it predicts does not depend on total cross-section forces only, as it is affected by the division of M(x) in two contributions which can be chosen by imposing the natural boundary conditions. This beam model is quite complicated and it is one of the most accurate for not-too-soft cores, as, among the relevant contributions to the sandwich deflection, it only neglects the direct core deformability along its thickness, εy. In fact, Heller [12] used the predictions of the zig-zag model as reference in order to establish whether the classical FOSD modelling is accurate enough in the stress computation. Heller [12] concluded that ϵ should not be much less than 1 and γ should not be much larger than 0. Here, we provide a much more precise evaluation of those limits. Sharma and Rao [13] obtained the analytical solutions for most cases of practical interest by solving the equations governing the zig-zag model with the assumption of antiplane sandwich and by neglecting the shear deformation of the skins. Here, we will show that in the antiplane case the zig-zag model is not accurate enough and one should resort to Frostig's model. Sudhakar et al. [14] developed a finite element to implement a sandwich model which shares some features with the zig-zag and Frostig models: the skins are treated as Timoshenko beams whose transversal displacements are allowed to be different and the core is antiplane, but, contrariwise to Frostig's model, the model of Sudhakar et al. [14] neglects the contribution due to the normal stress σy along the core thickness. Figure 1.
Zig-zag warping.

Other beam models neglecting the core deformation εy while accounting for all the other relevant data (consisting in the bending and shear deformability of both core and skins) have been developed in literature (see, e.g. the review of Ghugal and Shimpi [15]). Among those models alternative to the zig-zag theory, the most relevant class is that of the single-layer theories, in which the cross-section displacement field is a C∞ continuous function. A meaningful example for sandwiches is given by the third-order model of Silverman [16], while the reader is, for instance, referred to Khdeir and Reddy [17], Yu and Hodges [18], and Tessler et al. [19] for more general discussions on composite laminated beams. Single-layer models are easier to deal with than the zig-zag theory, but the latter is known to be more accurate. In fact, we will show that the zig-zag theory is extremely accurate when εy can be neglected.

By defining the beam slenderness as (3)λ=hL with h = c + 2t the cross-section height and L the characteristic length of the stress state [3], we assume that the relative stiffness between core and skins, say ℋ, be a function of ϵ, γ, and λ (4)H=H(ε,γ,λ) and, for the sake of brevity, we call ℋ the sandwich heterogeneity.

We wish to provide some operative tools for the ‘switch of modelling’ described above. Hence, we will provide some graphs or operative formulae for eant(γ,λ)anded S V(γ,λ) We note that the rigourous mathematical particularisation of elasticity solutions for continua to the case of antiplane sandwich beam is an open problem. For instance, Serpilli and Lenci [20], whose purpose was the validation of structural models by means of a proper limit process involving asymptotic expansions of the solutions for two-dimensional continuum models, found a lack of convergence for a sandwich beam in the limit ϵ → 0.

Finally, we will show that our calculations numerically extend to the case of thick skins the result of Berdichevsky [3], who categorised the need of different models on the basis of the following single parameter Gcγ Gs where Gs and Gc are the shear moduli of skins and core, respectively, relevant for the deformation in the (x, y) plane.

sec.title: The benchmark and its modelling
sec.p:
In order to avoid the relevant complications concerning statistically indeterminate structures, we focus our attention on a simply supported sandwich beam subject to a uniform transversal load q (i.e. acting along the y-direction). The benchmark is depicted in Figure 2, where symmetry is accounted for. The choice of a statistically determinate sandwich makes things much easier for the FOSD modelling (see e.g. Bardella [2]) because the bending moment M(x) = qx(L − x/2) and shear force V(x) = q(L − x) are known independent of the sandwich deformability, which is difficult to be accurately evaluated within the FOSD theory [2] Figure 2.
Schematic of the benchmark adopted..

For the benchmark here of interest, we take the most severe loading condition, as we apply the reaction forces at the corner points of the lower skin (y = c/2 + t, x = 0 and x = 2L), while the distributed load is applied on the external surface of the upper skin (y = − c/2 − t), as represented in Figure 2. This allows us to investigate the load diffusion accompanied with the beam deflection. Also, we point out that the chosen benchmark has the peculiarity of requiring, in order to reach the equilibrium, the interaction of the two skins, for any value of ϵ (i.e. independent of the core compliance). This would not be the case of other interesting boundary value problems, such as the cantilever sandwich beam subject to transversal loading on one skin.

All the results are obtained for isotropic materials with Poisson ratio ν = 0.3 for both skins and core. This datum is unnecessary for the evaluation of the stress state by means of the FOSD modelling, while it enters both the finite element simulations and the zig-zag model, and it relates the relevant Young's and shear moduli of the core in the Frostig model.

sec.title: The finite element model
sec.p:
In the finite element simulations, run with the code ABAQUS [21], the sandwiches are discretised by means of eight-noded plane stress continuum elements with reduced integration. The symmetry of the problem allows the modelling of half region by imposing zero displacements along x at the midspan nodes (x = L). The accuracy of the results has been checked by properly refining the mesh, case by case. An example is given in Figure 3, which represents the detail around the support of one of the most refined mesh. The mesh is represented on the deformed shape of a sandwich with very high heterogeneity ℋ, given by the selection ϵ = 1.E-5, γ = 1/3, and λ = 3/20. Other data are q = 50 N/mm, h = 30 mm, and b = 50 mm, the latter being the cross-section width. Coarser meshes have been employed for milder heterogeneities. Figure 3.
The detail of the deformed mesh at the support region with the contour of the longitudinal normal stress in one of the most extreme cases of sandwich heterogeneity ℋ: λ = 3/20, γ = 1/3, and ϵ = 1.E−5.

As already noticed, the actual way in which the support condition is achieved is extremely important when ϵ becomes very small; here, we consider the most severe situation by concentrating the support reaction force in the bottom corner node, opposite to the skin where the distributed load is applied. The reason for this choice, whose effect is quite clear in Figure 3, is to obtain conservative results in terms of the predictive capability of the analytical models presented in the following sections.

The results of the finite element analyses will be taken, in `The comparison between the predictions of the analytical models and the results of finite element simulations' section, as reference in the critical evaluation of the analytical models.

sec.title: The analytical models
sec.p: Here we provide a brief summary of the models concerned in this study, with particular reference to the benchmark under study.

sec.title: FOSD modelling
sec.p: By assuming no warping, the normal stresses read (6)σx(i)=qx(L-x/2)EiDy where i = s in the skins and i = c in the core and D is the FOSD estimation of the bending stiffness (7)D=Es(bt36+bt(c+t)22)+Ecbc312 The shear stresses are estimated by Jourawski's [22] theory. By considering the shear stress components along the shear force direction y and its normal z, Jourawski's theory estimates τ¯xz=0 everywhere whereas (8)τ¯xy(x,y)={q(L-x)Es2D[(t+c2)2-y2]if|y|∈[c/2, c/2+t]q(L-x)2D[Est(t+c)+Ec(c24-y2)]if|y|∈[0, c/2]

sec.title: Structural theory based on the zig-zag kinematics
sec.p: The warping of a symmetric sandwich section can be represented quite accurately by a piecewise linear axial displacement described through the three unknown functions v, λc, and λs, such that v(x) is the deflection of the sandwich longitudinal axis x and, by denoting with ′ a derivative computed with respect to x, (9)φc(x)=λc(x)v'(x) and (10)φs(x)=λs(x)v'(x) are the total cross-section rotations of the core and of the skins, respectively (see Figure 1 and the works [1, 2, 6, 7]). Under this assumption, the total potential energy (TPE) functional Ψ for a sandwich beam subject to a uniformly distributed transversal load q reads (11)Ψ(v,λc,λs)=Gcbc2∫0ℓ[(1-λc)v']2dx+Ecbc324∫0ℓ[(λcv')']2dx+Gsbt∫0ℓ[(1-λs)v']2dx+Esbt312∫0ℓ[(λsv')']2dx+Esbt4∫0ℓ{[(cλc+tλs)v']'}2dx-q∫0ℓv(x)dx with ℓ the beam length, equal to 2L in the chosen benchmark. The actual solution of the problem corresponds to (12)min(v,λc,λs)∈KΨ(v,λc,λs) where, for a simply supported sandwich beam K={v(x),λc(x),λs(x):v(x)∈C1[0,ℓ],v(0)=v(ℓ)=0,λc(x)∈C0[0,ℓ],λs(x)∈C0[0,ℓ]} is the set enclosing all the compatible fields. Note that one of the very few cases in which λc and λs are subject to essential boundary conditions is that of a beam end with no warping allowed, in which λc = λs (or even λc = λs = 1).

Within this approach, the structural constitutive laws are given by (13)M(x)=-Esbt36φs'(x)-Esbt22[cφc'(x)+tφs'(x)]︸Ms(x)-Esbtc2[cφc'(x)+tφs'(x)]-Ecbc312φc'(x)︸Mc(x) (14)V(x)=Gcbc[v'(x)-φc(x)]+2Gsbt[v'(x)-φs(x)] and the natural boundary conditions leave the freedom to specify separately the contributions Ms and Mc, due to the variations of ϕs and ϕc, respectively. That is, the same total bending moment M on a beam section can be applied by any combination of Ms and Mc such that M = Ms + Mc, thus obtaining a different solution in terms of stresses for each choice of Ms and Mc. For this reason, this model is not ‘à la de Saint-Venant’.

The solution can be obtained by directly minimising the TPE (11) by means of the Ritz method, in a way similar to that followed in Bardella [2] (more details are given in Tonelli [23]). The normal stress is then obtained as (15)σx(x,y)={-Es[φc'(x)c2sgn(y)+φs'(x)(y-c2sgn(y))]if|y|∈[c/2, c/2+t]-Ecφc'(x)yif|y|∈[0, c/2]

sec.title: Improved shear stress evaluation
sec.p: In order to have an accurate estimate of the shear stress, we follow Bardella and Tonelli [9] and apply the Jourawski [22] approach to the zig-zag kinematics. The shear stress average along chords parallel to the neutral axis turns out to read (16)τ¯xy(x,y)={Es{φs″(x)12[(|y|-c2)2-t2]-φc″(x)c2(c2+t-|y|)}if|y|∈[c/2, c/2+t]Ecφc″(x)12(y2-c24)+τ¯xyint(x)if|y|∈[0, c/2] where (17)τ¯xyint(x)=-Est2[φs″(x)t+φc″(x)c] is the interface shear stress τ¯xy(x,y=|c/2|). The above estimate can be evaluated after the minimisation of functional (11) delivers the functions v(x), λs(x), and λc(x). The analytic solution is given in Bardella and Tonelli [9] and, for the shear stress average on the neutral axis, reads (18)τ¯xy(ξ)=qbkA3[A1e-k(1-ξ)-e-kξ1+e-k+A2(1-2ξ)] where ξ = x/ℓ and, with η = γ/ϵ (19)A1=6ℓc[1+4η(1+γ)]+EsGsk2tℓγ[GsGc-2(1+η)] (20)A2=3kℓc[1+4η(1+γ)] , A3=4[1+2η(3+6γ+4γ2)] (21)k=ℓt3A32(2+3η)EsGs(1+2GsGcγ) In Bardella and Tonelli [9] it is shown that the estimate (18) is extremely accurate for a very large range of sandwich heterogeneity ℋ, when the boundary conditions are applied to the reference finite element model in such a way as to minimise the effect of the lack of Saint-Venant principle. In particular, in the finite element simulations of Bardella and Tonelli [9], contrariwise to the benchmark here of interest and described in `The benchmark and its modelling' section, the support was modelled by setting to zero the displacement component along y of all the nodes in the section at x = 0, and the distributed load was applied to both the top and bottom skins.

sec.title: The higher-order theory of Frostig et al [10, 11]
sec.p: For the benchmark here of interest, this higher-order theory [10, 11] is governed by the following TPE functional, here expressed in terms of the transversal and axial displacements in the core, v(x, y) and u(x, y), respectively, in order to emphasise the assumption of thin skins (22)Ψ[v(x,y),u(x,y)]=b∫0L{∫-c/2c/2Ec(∂v(x,y)∂y)2dy+cGc(∂u(x,y)∂y+∂v(x,y)∂x︸γxy(c)(x))2 +Est[112(t∂2v(x,y=-c/2)∂x2)2+(∂u(x,y=-c/2)∂x+t2∂2v(x,y=-c/2)∂x2)2 +112(t∂2v(x,y=c/2)∂x2)2+(∂u(x,y=c/2)∂x-t2∂2v(x,y=c/2)∂x2)2]}dx -2q∫0Lv(x,y=-c/2)dx where, as already noticed, the neglection of the normal stress σx in the core makes the shear stress τxy(c)=Gcγxy(c) uniform along y. The relevant kinematic boundary conditions are (23)v(x=0,y=c/2)=0 which imposes vanishing transversal displacement at the bottom skin in the supported section and (24)(u(x,y=±c/2)∓t2∂v(x,y=±c/2)∂x)|x=L=0 ∂v(x,y=±c/2)∂x|x=L=0 for the absence of axial displacements and rotations, respectively, in the two skins at the section of symmetry.

The minimisation of functional (22) under the essential conditions (23) and (24) leads to the following balance equations and natural boundary conditions for u(x, y) and v(x, y), through γxy(c)(x)=∂u/∂y+∂v/∂x (25)Gc∂γxy(c)(x)∂x+Ec∂2v(x,y)∂y2=0 x∈[0,L] y∈[-c/2,c/2] (26)Est(∂2u(x,y=±c/2)∂x2∓t2∂3v(x,y=±c/2)∂x3)∓Gcγxy(c)(x)=0 x∈[0,L] (27)Est312∂4v(x,y=c/2)∂x4-Gct2∂γxy(c)(x)∂x+Ec∂v(x,y)∂y|y=c/2=0 x∈[0,L] (28)Est312∂4v(x,y=-c/2)∂x4-Gct2∂γxy(c)(x)∂x-Ec∂v(x,y)∂y|y=-c/2+qb=0 x∈[0,L] (29)(∂u(x,y=±c/2)∂x∓t2∂2v(x,y=±c/2)∂x2)|x=0=0 ∂2v(x,y=±c/2)∂x2|x=0=0 for the absence of axial forces and bending moments applied on the skins in the supported section, (30)∂3v(x,y=-c/2)∂x3|x=0=0 (∂u(x,y)∂y+∂v(x,y)∂x)|x=0=0 for the absence of shear applied on the upper skin and on the core in the supported section, and (31)∂3v(x,y=±c/2)∂x3|x=L=0 (∂u(x,y)∂y+∂v(x,y)∂x)|x=L=0 given the absence of shear along the section of symmetry.

For more details, the reader is referred to the papers of Frostig et al. [10, 11] Here, let us just add that, in order to obtain the solution, there is the need to solve an eighth-order algebraic equation and we have implemented the model in the software Mathematica [24]. Finally, we emphasise that this model is not ‘à la de Saint-Venant’ as it predicts a mechanical response dependent on how the generalised forces are applied on the cross sections. For instance, if we wanted to distribute the support reaction force on the two skins, we could substitute the first of the natural boundary conditions (30) with the essential boundary condition v(x = 0, y = − c/2) = 0.

sec.title: The comparison between the predictions of the analytical models and the results of finite element simulations
The criterion of comparison and the representation of its outcome
sec.p: Here, we define how we compare the predictions of the analytical models considered with the results of the finite element simulations.

The outcome of the comparison is the distance d from the support, represented in Figure 4, defining the sandwich region x ∈ [d, L] where the stress state predicted by the analytical models becomes almost coincident with that of the finite element analysis. This is considered to be the case when the relative error between the normal longitudinal stresses in the two Gauss points farthest from the neutral axis z is less than 1%. This choice has been guided by several numerical tests (reported in detail in Tonelli [23] and Minelli [25]) which have shown that it usually requires a shorter distance for the shear stresses to converge. Also, tests performed by choosing different maximum relative errors have shown the appropriateness of setting it to 1%. The code to obtain d for each selection of ϵ, γ, and λ has been implemented in the software Mathematica [24], where the stresses predicted by analytical models are compared with the results of finite element simulations in each Gauss point by reading the ABAQUS output dat file. Figure 4.
Sketch of the benchmark with the notation employed to indicate the region x ∈ [d, L] where the models analysed accurately predict the stress state.

For what concerns the FOSD theory, the distance d may be called the stress diffusion distance and it would be approximately equal to the cross-section height, h = c + 2t, if Saint-Venant's principle held. The obvious expectation is that as ϵ decreases d/h increases, because the softer the core with respect to the skins, the more difficult for the stresses to propagate from one skin to the other.

Instead, one of the main purposes of the higher-order model of Frostig et al. [10, 11] is the description of the stress state also within the diffusion zone. This notwithstanding, we still expect an unlimited range of values of ϵ (i.e. ∀ ϵ > eant) in which the Frostig model cannot accurately represent the stresses, because of the antiplane assumption. Hence, contrary to the FOSD model, when the Frostig model is concerned, we expect to evaluate an increase in d as ϵ augments. For the sake of a deeper understanding of Frostig's [10, 11] higher-order model, we will also give an insight on what happens for extreme low values of ϵ, albeit this is unimportant for the applications (and difficult to predict).

With relation to the zig-zag model, we will show that such a modelling can effectively predict the stress state whenever Frostig's model becomes inaccurate, for sandwiches in which the core longitudinal stress should be accounted for. We note that the above-stated fact about the shear and normal stress convergence (i.e. it takes a shorter distance for the former to converge), in the comparison with the finite element results, holds also for the zig-zag model only if the improved shear stress evaluation (16) is employed. Otherwise, if the shear stress is assumed to be piecewise uniform, as a consequence of the chosen zig-zag kinematics, for many selections of ϵ, γ, and λ, it is the shear stress that gives the most restrictive condition and sets the value of d.

sec.title: Numerical results and discussion
sec.p:
First of all, we focus on the predictions of the FOSD and Frostig models, because of the physical meaning of their limits of validity. Some of the results obtained are collected in Figures 5 and 6 for eight different values of γ in the cases λ = 3/20 and λ = 3/40, respectively. The curves approaching from the left an asymptote along an axis parallel to d/h indicate the distance d from the support after which the solution predicted by the Frostig model gets very close to that of the finite element simulation (by meeting the criterion described in the previous section), whereas the curves approaching an analogous asymptote from the right are referred to the analogous comparison for the FOSD model. Figure 6.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where either the FOSD or the Frostig models inaccurately predict the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/40. FOSD: first-order shear deformation. Figure 5.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where either the FOSD or the Frostig models inaccurately predict the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/20. FOSD: first-order shear deformation.

The main result consists in the fact that, for each slenderness λ, there is a range ℰ of ϵ dependent on γ, as expressed by equation (5), in which both models inaccurately predict the stress state in a large sandwich region (that is, if ϵ ∈ ℰ, then d is much larger than 2h for both the FOSD and Frostig models). Of course, ℰ is an increasing function of γ ∈ (0, 1]. Only the case of a quite slender beam, with λ = 3/40, having extremely thin skins, in particular γ = 1/118, can be quite satisfactorily described by the FOSD and Frostig models for any value of ϵ, granted the knowledge of the value of ϵ, equal to eant(γ=1/118,λ=3/40)≈ed S V(γ=1/118,λ=3/40)≈3.E-4 (see equation (5)), at which one should switch model; of course, for such a case, ℰ ≈ Ø.

Figures 7 and 8 focus on the results concerned with the Frostig model, while the graphs in Figures 9 and 10 give the detail for the FOSD model only. The peculiar behaviour reported in Figures 7 and 8 can be explained by the competition between the facts that when ϵ decreases, on the one hand, the connection of the two skins is more difficult but, on the other hand, the Frostig model gets closer to the real behaviour as the longitudinal stress σx within the core becomes really negligible. However, the asymptotic behaviour for extremely low value of ϵ (of little interest for the applications) seems to suggest that in that case the accurate modelling of the stress diffusion requires the accounting for σx in the core. The cusps exhibited by most of the d(ϵ) curves (see, for instance, in Figure 7, the curve related to γ = 1/3 at ϵ ≈ 3.E−3) correspond to changes in the skin where a longer distance from the support is required for the stress to converge. Figure 7.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where the Frostig model inaccurately predicts the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/20. Figure 8.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where the Frostig model inaccurately predicts the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/40. Figure 9.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where the FOSD model inaccurately predicts the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/20. FOSD: first-order shear deformation. Figure 10.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where the FOSD model inaccurately predicts the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/40. FOSD: first-order shear deformation.

Figure 11, referred to λ = 3/20, shows that the gap resulting from the use of the FOSD and Frostig models can be covered using the zig-zag model. More precisely, the combined use of the zig-zag and Frostig models allows the accurate description of the sandwich stress state, almost everywhere after a distance not much larger than the sandwich height from concentrated loads, for any selection of the parameters γ, λ, and ϵ. However, the discussion of the results of the FOSD model remains extremely interesting because (a) the limit of the FOSD model represents the limit of the validity of Saint-Venant's principle in sandwich beams and (b) the FOSD model is the simplest one, so that it is good to know when it can be successfully applied. We emphasise that the boundary conditions considered here lead to a stress diffusion very difficult to be described analytically and which requires a relatively large region of the continuum to stabilise in the sense of Saint-Venant's principle, when it holds. In the case of thin skins (in particular, in our simulations, γ = 1/118) one has to resort to the Frostig model only for extremely high contrast of moduli (ϵ < 6.E−6), though the Frostig model provides good results for the larger set ε<eant(γ=1/118,λ=3/20)≈1.E-4 Instead, in the case of thick skins (i.e. γ = 1/3), the zig-zag modelling must be used for ϵ > 0.02, while Frostig's model has to be employed for ε<eant(γ=1/3,λ=3/20)≈0.02 The results for different values of the slenderness λ are qualitatively similar to those presented in Figure 11 and will be summarised later in other graphs. Figure 11.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where either the zig-zag or the Frostig models inaccurately predict the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/20.

Tables 1 to 4 report some data from the predictions of the zig-zag model in terms of λc(0) = ϕc(0)/v′(0) and λs(0) = ϕs(0)/v′(0), which give a quite precise evaluation of the warping at the simply supported beam end. It is quite interesting to see that, among the cases considered in those tables, only the sandwich having maximum heterogeneity ℋ (corresponding to λ = 3/20, γ = 1/8, ϵ = 1.E−4 – see the last row of Table 4) exhibits a warping very close to the simplified kinematics proposed by Allen [1] to describe the behaviour of an antiplane sandwich, that is λs = 1 and λc = − t/c = −0.125. However, under this extreme condition, Figure 12 shows that the zig-zag model describes quite inaccurately the stress state and one should resort to the Frostig model, as eant(γ=1/8,λ=3/20)≈3.E-3 Instead, in the example under discussion (λ = 3/20 and γ = 1/8), it is worthwhile to adopt the zig-zag model for 0.06 < ϵ < 0.15, as for about ε>ed S V(γ=1/8,λ=3/20)≈0.15 one may use the classical FOSD model (Figure 5). Note that the results of Tables 1 to 4 are obtained by means of the Ritz method, as reported in Tonelli [23] (see also Bardella [2]). Table 1.
Warping predicted by the zig-zag model for the case λ = 3/40 and γ = 1/28.

Figure 12.
Amplitude of the region x ∈ [0, d] where either the zig-zag or the Frostig models inaccurately predict the sandwich stress state in the case λ = 3/20 and γ = 1/8.

sec.title: On the definition of antiplane sandwich
sec.p:
Figure 13 compares our results in terms of the variable eant(γ, λ), i.e. the value of ϵ over which the higher-order theory of Frostig starts becoming inaccurate, which represents, in our view, an accurate numerical definition of antiplane sandwich. We note that, for most choices of γ and λ, eant(γ, λ) is numerically well characterised by the sharp change in slope of the curves d(λ, γ, ϵ), as for instance shown in Figures 7 and 8. Figure 13 also considers the two classical definitions of antiplane sandwich given by Allen [1]. The definition based on the closeness to uniformity of the shear stress along the core reads, in our notation: (32)eant(τ)=0.04γ(1+γ) by which if ε<eant(τ) the sandwich is antiplane. Instead, Allen's criterion relying on the FOSD kinematics and a negligible contribution of the core on the bending stiffness D given by equation (7) reads: (33)eant(D)=0.06γ(1+γ)2 with ε<eant(D) in the antiplane case. Figure 13.
On the definition of aniplane sandwich: comparison between the classical criteria of Allen [1] – see equations (32) and (33) — and our numerical results in terms of eant and its fitting given by equation (34).

From Figure 13 it is evicted that definition (33) constitutes an upper bound to our numerical results, while definition (32) is in most cases a lower bound, with the exception of short sandwiches with thin skins.

By numerically exploring the ranges 3/40 ≤ λ ≤ 3/10 and 1/118 ≤ γ ≤ 1/3 , we have obtained the following numerical fitting (34)eant(γ,λ)≈(-3.082×10-1λ2+8.933×10-2λ+1.499×10-1)γ2+(1.713×10-1λ2-1.881×10-1λ+5.940×10-2)γ-6.254×10-3λ2+1.289×10-3λ-3.261×10-4 The operative definition of antiplane sandwich ε≤eant(γ,λ) has the advantage, with respect to that of the classical one given by Allen [1], that it is not based on the Bernoulli–Navier hypothesis for the cross-section kinematics. Instead, one of its limitations is the assumption of thin skins which is based on. Such an assumption, albeit usually satisfied in sandwiches with very soft core, makes the expression (34) possibly less accurate than what desired for about γ > 1/10.

Swanson and Kim [26] compared Frostig's theory with finite element analyses for the same boundary value problem exploited here, with a selection of data corresponding to ϵ = 1.926E−3, γ = 1/18, λ = 1/10. From equation (34), one estimates, for γ = 1/18 and λ = 1/10, eant = 2.571E−3 > ϵ = 1.926E−3, which means that Frostig's theory should be accurate in describing the stress state in the sandwich considered by Swanson and Kim [26], at a distance comparable with the sandwich height from concentrated loads. This is in fact what Swanson and Kim [26] found.

sec.title: On the limit of validity of Saint-Venant's principle
sec.p:
Figure 14 represents the limit of validity of the FOSD modelling in terms of edSV, evaluated numerically within our comparison with the results of finite element simulations. In order to give a further insight on the amplitude of the range ℰ defined in equation (5), in Figure 14 we have also plotted Allen's upper bound (33) for the definition of antiplane sandwich. Figure 14.
On the validity of Saint-Venant's principle: our results in terms of edSV compared for reference with Allen's definition of antiplane sandwich given by equation (33).

The definition of edSV(γ, λ) based on curves similar to those plotted in Figures 9 and 10 is more difficult than the analogous operation previously done to numerically obtain eant(γ, λ), based on Frostig's model and resulting in equation (34), because the plots relevant for the FOSD model exhibit a quite smooth increase in d/h as ϵ decreases.

sec.title: The Berdichevsky criterion
sec.p: Berdichevsky [3] proposes the following criterion: (35)Gcγ Gs=λα with α = 2 the watershed between situations in which the classical bending theory works (for 0 < α < 2) and antiplane sandwiches (α > 2), α = 2 being the only case requiring the computation of the shear deformation through the solution of a boundary value problem. Since, in this study, we have considered isotropic materials with the same Poisson's ratio for both core and skins, the parameter ϵ coincides with the ratio Gc/Gs of the Berdichevsky [3] criterion.

For the case λ = 3/20, Figure 15 compares our results with the criterion (35) proposed by Berdichevsky in order to establish which model should be used in order to predict the sandwich stress state. In Figure 15, our results have to be read as follows. For a given γ, if ϵ ≥ edSV, the classical FOSD theory is accurate enough to predict the sandwich stress state; instead, if ϵ ≤ eant, then the Frostig higher-order theory should be used, as the sandwich is really antiplane. The zig-zag model is accurate enough for ϵ ≥ eant. Therefore, the criterion (35) agrees with our numerical observations when it falls between the dashed and dot–dashed fitting curves of Figure 15. We observe a quite large disagreement for γ > 0.02, i.e. in those cases where the assumption of thin skins is violated. Figure 15.
Comparison between the Berdichevsky [3] criterion and our results.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: For simply supported sandwich beams subject to uniform loading, we have evaluated the stress field predicted by three analytical models by comparison with accurate numerical results obtained from finite element simulations. We have considered the classical FOSD modelling based on the cross-section linear kinematics (e.g. Allen [1]), the zig-zag structural theory (Yu [6], Krajcinovic [7, 8], and Bardella and Tonelli [9]), and the higher-order theory of Frostig et al. [10, 11].
The choice of evaluating these models among those available in literature has been guided by many facts that are listed below.

Each of those models is very accurate for a certain range of sandwich heterogeneity ℋ(ϵ, γ, λ) (here assumed to be a function of the Young's modulus ratio ϵ = Ec/Es, the relative thickness of skins and core γ = t/c, and the beam slenderness λ = h/L), and it is difficult to a priori know which model should be used for a specific sandwich, with given ϵ, γ, and λ. One of the purposes of this study is giving an insight on this.

For each model, we have numerically identified several combinations of ϵ, γ, and λ which establish limits out of which the model considered loses accuracy quite rapidly. Here and henceforth, we synthesise this concept with the phrase ‘limit of accuracy’.

The limit of accuracy of Frostig's model [10, 11] is here seen as a quite precise physical definition of antiplane sandwich. In this sense, the outcome of our calculations has been used to discuss the classical definitions given by Allen [1] of antiplane sandwich.

The limit of accuracy of the FOSD modelling is instead here seen as the limit of validity of Saint-Venant's principle, because the FOSD theory is the only one in which the stress depends only on the total bending moment and shear force applied on the considered cross section. Besides allowing this per se interesting discussion, the evaluation of the circumstances under which the FOSD modelling is accurate is, of course, very important as the FOSD theory is the simplest one to apply.

We have found that the FOSD and Frostig models may be inadequate to accurately describe the stress state for certain values of the heterogeneity ℋ(ϵ, γ, λ), whereas the zig-zag model allows one to fill this gap. In particular, our calculations show that the zig-zag model always offers a satisfactory accuracy when the Frostig model does not, and vice versa. Hence, we have provided an empirical analytic expression fitting of our numerical results which gives, for large ranges of ϵ, γ, and λ, the function ϵ(γ, λ) ≡ eant(γ, λ) at which one should switch model, corresponding to our numerical definition of antiplane sandwich.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Professor Stefano Lenci is acknowledged for helpful discussions. The finite element code ABAQUS and the software Mathematica have been run at DICATA, University of Brescia, Italy, under academic license.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was done within a research project financed by the Italian Ministry of Education, University, and Research (MIUR).
